title: Gambits
content:
# Gambits

A gambit is a calculated conversation piece designed to elicit a specific reaction from someone. These gambits come in many categories and can be adapted to your model.

IMPORTANT: DO NOT JUST COPY PASTE THESE AND DO NOTHING ELSE, IT WILL LOOK FAKE AS FUCK.

You have to throw some fluff in there in between each phase. Simple comments, a few messages, etc. 

These can be as effective or even more effective as selling PPVs.

Transitional gambits

Captain Save A Ho Gambits

Emotional connection

title: Billy
content:
# Billy

3/9/2025

Proposal of the day: Vault Optimization and Maintenance Plan

Why do I want to do this?
To streamline and organize the vault for improved efficiency, productivity, and resource utilization. A well-structured vault will enhance workflow, reduce downtime, and ultimately boost sales.

Current Issues with the Vault:

- Clutter: Unnecessary photos and videos are taking up space, making navigation difficult.
- Poor Organization: Content folders are not properly segregated or named, forcing chatters to scroll endlessly instead of using the search function.
- Lack of Descriptions: Videos lack descriptions, requiring chatters to watch them to understand their content.
- Unoptimized Custom Content: Custom-made videos are scattered and not tagged properly, making them difficult to reuse or repurpose.
- Can't utilize the search button because of the things I mentioned above.

Billy, as I have told you, this is your responsibility. Fix it yourself. But Why are we not doing it?

- Chatters lack admin access, limiting their ability to make necessary changes.
- Fear of disrupting the current system or overstepping authority (a cultural tendency among Filipino workers).
- Bad habits and familiarity with the current chaotic system have become ingrained.
- Time constraints: Chatters prioritize selling over organizing, as they are not compensated for vault maintenance.

Proposed Solutions:
Dedicated Vault Maintenance Period:

Schedule a 2-3 day shutdown to focus solely on organizing the vault.

Assign chatters to specific tasks such as deleting unnecessary files, segregating content, adding descriptions, and tagging custom videos. Writing description, as a matter of fact. Let's include the Scripts button in OF on the maintenance.

- Compensation for Maintenance Work: Pay chatters for their time spent on vault organization to ensure focus and commitment.
- Contest Incentive: Turn the maintenance into a friendly competition. Reward the team or individual who creates the most organized and efficient vault structure.

Admin Support:

Grant temporary admin access to selected chatters to facilitate the reorganization process.

Benefits of Vault Optimization

- Increased Productivity: A well-organized vault could lead to a 100-300% boost in productivity and speed.
- Faster access to resources means more time for engaging with subscribers and closing sales.
- Resource Maximization: Custom-made videos can be reused for other subscribers with similar preferences, doubling the value of existing content.

A future/side benefit:

- Improved Training and Collaboration: New chatters can be trained more efficiently.
- Easier knowledge sharing among team members.
- Emergency Preparedness: Example, during sudden influxes of subscribers or unexpected absences, chatters can quickly locate and utilize resources.
- Enhanced User Experience: Chatters can focus more into giving the subs more quality chatting, Subscribers will benefit from quicker, more tailored interactions, leading to higher satisfaction and retention rates.

Rationale for the maintenance:
The current chaotic state of the vault has become a deeply ingrained part of the workflow. While everyone recognizes the benefits of organization, the inertia of bad habits and the fear of disrupting the status quo have prevented meaningful change. A dedicated, structured effort is required to break these patterns and implement a system that will yield long-term benefits.

Projected Outcomes:
Sales Growth: A 100-300% increase in sales is projected due to improved efficiency and resource utilization.
Operational Efficiency: Reduced downtime and faster access to content will enhance overall performance.
Team Morale: A well-organized system will reduce frustration and create a more positive work environment.

Billy's Parting speech:



3/20/2025



3/21/2025



3/22/2025

title: 1% better every day
content:
# 1% better every day

I read something that said that if you improve 1% every day for a year, then thanks to compound interest that means that over the course of a year you will have improved by 2800%.

While I don’t really understand the math on that, I understand the spirit of the rule.

If you focus on just becoming a tiny bit better every day in as many areas as you can think of, then over an extended period of time, you will turn into an absolute monster.

When I’m out in the world, I think to myself, “get 1% better, get 1% better” - I just repeat it over and over to myself in my head.

And you know what? It actually works.

It’s improved my workouts, my relationships, my finances, my work ethic - everything. 

I’m not making crazy big changes either, just tiny things. But over time those tiny things build up.

And chatting is FULL of tiny things that can be improved.

So when you are working, think to yourself, “get 1% better” and figure out what you can do to do your job better. I promise that it will help over time.
source_file: Chatter Marines Field Handbook\Mindset\1% better every day 10b764e8a66e8001b966dee5a3def3ee.md

title: All it takes is 1 good sub to turn your day/week/month around
content:
# All it takes is 1 good sub to turn your day/week/month around

We’ll talk about this more later, but making a lot of money with chatting is less about selling to everyone and more about selling as much as possible to a small number of people.

The challenge is identifying who these people are and then coming up with reasons to get them to give you money.

We will teach you to do all that, but you need to understand that you don’t need to sell to 25 people every day to hit your numbers.

All you need is to find 1 good sub, show him a good experience, and use different gambits every time to get money from him.

There are subs who spend $5000-$10,000/month and much more. It’s just up to you to find them and cultivate a relationship.

Again, we will teach you to do all that, but understand that most of the money in chatting comes from a small number of subscribers.

And you only need 1 good one to turn a bad day into a good day, a bad week into a good week, or a bad month into a good month.
source_file: Chatter Marines Field Handbook\Mindset\All it takes is 1 good sub to turn your day week m 10b764e8a66e806fb5c5cda8e78a7ebb.md

title: Ask for the money
content:
# Ask for the money

Yes, chatting takes time to master.

But you can be good from day 1.

You can make $2000-$3000 in your first month as long as you follow the instructions.

There are chatters out there with bad English, bad social skills, bad reading comprehension, bad everything - who make a ton of money despite these things.

These people have no business making the amount of money that they do.

Likewise, there are people out there with amazing English, great social skills, incredible reading comprehension, good everything - who don’t make any money at all.

The difference between these two people is that the money makers do one thing that the non-money makers don’t:

They ask for the money.

Yes, from time to time you may get some subs who tip out of nowhere, but most of the time they are not lining up around the block to send you their money.

99% of the time you are going to have to ask for the money.

It’s not a comfortable thing to do.

You are risking the interaction, the relationship that you have built, and all the work and time that’s gone into it.

But unfortunately that’s what you have to do in order to make money.

Yes, there are lots of little tricks we can do to soften the ask, but you are still going to have to ask for the money.

Your bank account will thank you.
source_file: Chatter Marines Field Handbook\Mindset\Ask for the money 10b764e8a66e800db798c730305246cc.md

title: Every failure is a brick in your palace
content:
# Every failure is a brick in your palace

You have a lot to learn.

Chatting is not an easy thing to master.

There are a lot of different situations that you will find yourself in that you may not know how to handle.

You will experience frustration as you watch sales slip through your fingers.

Sometimes you’ll be talking to a sub who seems like they’ll spend a lot of money, only to become cold after you say something stupid.

You cannot become a master of chatting without making mistakes. 

As robust as this guide is, there is no substitute for experience in the field.

And sometimes that field experience will make you uncomfortable.

If you can deal with that discomfort, you will make a ton of money, change your life, and always be able to make money in any job if you ever stop working for me.

Remember: discomfort DOES NOT equal failure.

Failure is not trying. Failure is giving up.

You can be uncomfortable and still succeed.

You can feel gross, exhausted, angry, frustrated, and STILL have had a great day of sales that puts hundreds of dollars in your pocket.

In fact, it’s not likely that you will be able to separate discomfort from success.

And when it comes to chatting, you must become a master.

And that means not just being a master of chatting, but also a master of discomfort. 

Of course you should try to succeed, but learn to love the failures and struggles on the way.
source_file: Chatter Marines Field Handbook\Mindset\Every failure is a brick in your palace 39e0da5899e349cc8f51a70e8edd2d8e.md

title: Potential to change your life
content:
# Potential to change your life

So before we get into the actual tips, I want to talk to you about why you should even want to do this in the first place.

The bottom line is this: if you become good at this job, you will make 10x the average monthly salary in your country.

Imagine for a second what you would do if you had that much  money coming in every month.

You could travel wherever you want, go on shopping sprees, take girls to nice restaurants, buy a house or car for your family, start a business - anything.

Money will open a lot of doors for you.

But in order to get money, you need valuable skills which you probably don’t have.

Not only will this guide give them to you, but these skills can used immediately in a work environment that I provide to you.

I have models, they have subscribers to talk to, and plenty of content to sell.

All we need are people to sit on the accounts and do the work.

Bottom line, everything is set up for you to succeed.

And if you follow the instructions in this guide, you will succeed.

I have people working for me who were good from Day 1 - all because they followed my instructions.

I would love for you to be like them.

So do yourself a favor and pay attention to the rest of the information in this guide so you can start making money ASAP.
source_file: Chatter Marines Field Handbook\Mindset\Potential to change your life 10b764e8a66e80e688ccec3ec2cd848d.md

title: Rejection is part of the game
content:
# Rejection is part of the game

Let me be honest with you: you are not going sell every single person you talk to.

No chatter, regardless of how good they are, will sell to everyone.

In fact, you won’t even sell to the majority of them.

As you get better, you will get your conversion percentage higher as you learn to pull their emotional triggers and identify where you are in the process.

But on the whole, you are not going to sell to most of them, even if you’re a master.

This doesn’t mean you’re a bad person or a worthless human being, it just means that one sub ddn’t buy.

Assuming you did everything you were supposed to do, don’t beat yourself up if a sub doesn’t buy.

Now, that doesn’t mean you are allowed to do a half-assed job and then say “oh well guess he just didn’t buy.”

You still have to do the work properly.

But just understand that most people won’t buy and that’s OK.
source_file: Chatter Marines Field Handbook\Mindset\Rejection is part of the game 2cb30ce8b6de401c84d5d9695a32d725.md

title: Why you must set goals and give rewards
content:
# Why you must set goals and give rewards

Setting goals is absolutely crucial to success, regardless of what you’re focusing on.

The last section about becoming 1% better is really just impromptu goal setting to make tiny specific improvements.

And while that is really just an exercise in reminding yourself to set mini goals and achieve them instantly, there’s also a ton of value in setting bigger goals for yourself.

When you set goals for yourself, your brain will unconsciously drag you towards that outcome.

The more you focus on the goal, the more you repeat it to yourself, the more you remind yourself that it exists, the stronger the pull becomes.

For example, at the time of this writing, I have a goal of getting a roster of 8 high quality chatters. 

I’ve had this goal for months at this point and it’s much harder than I thought.

But just the fact that I set the goal for myself and told people about it makes me work much harder to achieving it.

Is there anything special about the number 8? Why not 7? Or 9?

It’s totally arbitrary.

But what’s important is that 8 was the number that I said I wanted, and 8 is what I’m going for.

Every time I look at my current roster and I see that there are less than 8 people who I KNOW are going to hit their targets every day, I get a little uncomfortable.

I don’t just there and wallow in my discomfort - I actively take steps to try to achieve my goal.

To help push me towards the goal even harder, I’ve set rewards for myself that I’ll only give myself when I achieve it. 

Things I want to buy, trips I want to take, ways I want to spoil myself a little bit.

So it makes me work harder.

You need to do the same thing for yourself. It doesn’t matter what the goal is, but set at least one for yourself and make sure it’s specific.

I will help you all set goals, don’t worry you won’t have to figure out the best way to do it on your own.
source_file: Chatter Marines Field Handbook\Mindset\Why you must set goals and give rewards 10b764e8a66e80398100d52d94ea75a3.md

title: Work all day no matter how much you’re on
content:
# Work all day no matter how much you’re on

Chatting is a job that can fuck with your emotions.

If you’re having a day where you sell a lot, you feel great.

You think to yourself, “Wow, I love chatting! I could do this forever!”

If you have a day where you’re struggling, you feel like shit.

You think, “I hate this chatting shit! I want to move to Costa Rica and become a yoga teacher.”

Trust me I know I’ve been there. I’ve experienced that many times.

The way chatting works is like this:

You will have an even amount of good days, bad days, and average days.

If you let your emotions rule you, then your numbers will drop.

You will take your foot off the gas on days where you are selling a lot.

You will become discouraged on days where you aren’t selling and think to yourself, “maybe today’s just not my day.”

Your average days will be just that - average.

But if you commit to working all day no matter how much you’re on, then here’s what will happen:

Your good days will become AMAZING days because you will ride your momentum to hit crazy numbers.

You will rescue your bad days because of your discipline and committment to working all day.

And your average days will be elevated to what you previously thought of as a “good” day because of your strong work ethic.

It’s not even about “being a good worker” or some other nebulous label. It’s about making as much as you can, and ultimately enjoying this job as much as possible.

Because as you’ll find out if you haven’t already, this job is a blast when you’re selling and a drag when it’s not.

But by using discipline to work at the same pace all day no matter what, you are ensuring that you keep the highs high and the lows less frequent.
source_file: Chatter Marines Field Handbook\Mindset\Work all day no matter how much you’re on 10b764e8a66e80ffb3eae412250ddb3f.md

title: You are not alone
content:
# You are not alone

If you’re reading this document, then it means you’re a lucky guy.

Why? Because I hired you.

And I am doing everything I can every day to make sure you make as much money as possible.

But here’s the problem: I’m a busy guy.

I don’t have time to take your temperature like mommy every day and make sure you’re doing well, your mind is right, or you don’t need anything.

You have to come to me and tell me. 

I’m not a mind reader.

If you have a problem, if something is wrong, or if you see an area where things can be improved, you need to come tell me.

It’s not “I would like you to” or “please if you feel like it” - no, I NEED you to come tell me.

I talk a lot about how I expect a lot from my chatters, and I know that sometimes people are scared to come to me with things because they are afraid that I will yell at them.

But unless you’re telling me how you fucked up and got an account locked because you did some dumb shit, I usually don’t react that way.

I am very very very interested in making as much money as possible. And you guys are the ones who are out there in the trenches bringing in the money.

So if you are struggling, need help with something, want more instruction/training, need a pep talk - whatever.

Come to me and talk to me about it.

You will also probably have a manager that you can go to as well and you can always ask the rest of the people on the team if you need help.
source_file: Chatter Marines Field Handbook\Mindset\You are not alone 10b764e8a66e80c29e7ec2ae229753a5.md

title: Advanced personalized openers
content:
# Advanced personalized openers

Sending personalized openers can be a great way to start conversations.

But let’s do a little comparison.

Let’s say we have a sub who’s username is @coffeeguy234 .

Opener 1:

Hey coffee guy! Bet you really like coffee. I’m more of a tea drinker myself.

Opener 2: 

Hey coffee guy!

Personally, I prefer tea

You know what that means

We are now enemies for life

We will fight on the battlefield in the great coffee and tea war of 2024

Whoever emerges victorious will rule Starbuckstopia forever

The first opener - while personalized - is boring and dry, doesn’t really show much effort, and isn’t particularly engaging.

The second one is much more fun, has a playful tone to it, and invites the sub to start roleplaying immediately.

Which one do you think is more likely to get a response?

If you are sending openers, don’t overthink it. Just type something out and hit enter, then do it again and hit enter again, so on until you’ve typed out about 5 separate short messages.

“
source_file: Chatter Marines Field Handbook\Opening\Advanced personalized openers 10b764e8a66e80ea83e2d79ff62fd7c8.md

title: Using voice notes as openers
content:
# Using voice notes as openers

All models who work for us get their voices cloned on ElevenLabs so the team can send voice notes. 

You will be given the logins to ElevenLabs so you can select your model’s voice and send personalized voice notes to new subscribers.

Voice notes are extremely powerful because subs are more likely to believe that it is actually the girl than if it’s just some text messages.

At the time of this writing, we are only now starting to experiment with these for openers, so I can’t advise you much on them.

But this will change over time as we get more data on what performs better.

For now, just send the openers that are a play on the sub’s username. You can experiment with longer vs shorter messages, but please make sure to make them personalized to the sub.

Also, use the “voice to voice” option.

And if you have anything less than perfect English, you MUST use Grammarly or Quillbot to check your phrasing before sending a voice note.

And remember: no profanity or explicit language in the voice notes.
source_file: Chatter Marines Field Handbook\Opening\Using voice notes as openers 2fa07c46f4014e17b84c9cfb95d0a5f5.md

title: Why we send personalized openers
content:
# Why we send personalized openers

Most of you have probably never subscribed to an OnlyFans account as a fan, so you haven’t seen things from their perspective.

The reality is that the customer experience for most fans is abysmal.

PPV spam, greedy and impatient chatters, and an overreliance on mass messages all contribute to this.

So what we do instead is send personalized openers.

A personalized opener is a play on the sub’s username that we include in the message.

So if their username is, “coffeeguy234,” then we could send them an opener like this:

“Hey coffee guy, I bet you really like coffee. Won’t you be happy to know I used to work at starbucks.”

I literally came up with that just now and yes, I am aware of how stupid it is.

But the purpose of sending the personalized opener is not so that you win awards for creativity or wit.

The purpose is to show the sub that 1) you have send the message to THEM specifically, and 2) to make a good first impression.

This is absolutely mandatory and so important that I have people who I’ve hired to send these so that closers can focus on selling.
source_file: Chatter Marines Field Handbook\Opening\Why we send personalized openers 10b764e8a66e804c8fe0c5dcf5aab9f9.md

title: Advanced fluff
content:
# Advanced fluff

In addition to advanced qualification, we have - you guessed it - advanced fluff (adfluff).

In simple terms, adfluff is really just expanding on whatever fluff you decide to insert in between the qualification and the commonality. 

So, what do you do for work? (qualification question)

I’m a computer programmer. (qualification)

Oh cool, so you’re like one of those tech geniuses who helps the FBI monitor my conversations with my grandma? Sounds fun. I hope you like the recipe she sent me for chocolate chip cookies. (adfluff)

How did you get into that? (adqual)

Adfluff is really just an extended observation or set of observations about whatever the sub said. 

You can be a little goofy and funny with it, but not too over the top. And please remember not to lapse into dicksucking.

The thing with fluff is that you can really insert it into any part of the conversation with a sub to pad out the convo and make it seem like more is being said than it really is. 

This is KEY to avoiding Robot Mode.

However, make sure you don’t END on fluff, always follow it up with qualification, commonality, or a gambit.

We’ll talk more about gambits in one of the later sections.
source_file: Chatter Marines Field Handbook\Qualifying, Commonalities, and Fluff\Advanced fluff 10b764e8a66e800cb7cee452937150e8.md

title: Advanced qualification
content:
# Advanced qualification

Don’t be intimidated by the title of this section. Advanced qualification (adqual from now on) is super easy and something you do in normal conversation every day.

Simply put, advanced qualification really just comes down to asking a follow up question to whatever the sub’s answer was.

So what do you do for work? (qualifying question)

I’m a computer programmer (qualification)

Oh really. How’d you get into that? (adqual)

These are things that you do when you are genuinely interested in learning more about a person.

And surprise surprise, developing a GENUINE INTEREST in subs will do wonders for your sales. But we’ll talk about that later.
source_file: Chatter Marines Field Handbook\Qualifying, Commonalities, and Fluff\Advanced qualification 10b764e8a66e807389e9f51ce91329e1.md

title: Avoiding Robot Mode
content:
# Avoiding Robot Mode

If all you do is build commonalities according to the process I outlined in the last section, you will already be better than 99% of working chatters.

However, if all you do is run through the cycle once and move onto the next topic, you will sound like a robot and be a super boring conversationalist.

The key to avoiding Robot Mode is to dive deeper into either the qualification, the fluff, or the commonality itself.
source_file: Chatter Marines Field Handbook\Qualifying, Commonalities, and Fluff\Avoiding Robot Mode 964fc4543ae34569a4fad70947d498df.md

title: Avoiding “interview mode”
content:
# Avoiding “interview mode”

I see this mistake a lot when I do roleplay sessions with new chatters. 

They go through the old training on qualifying/commonalities and think, “ok, I need specific info from the sub. I am going to go in there and just ask them a bunch of questions!”

What ends up happening though is that the conversation becomes very one sided and boring.

We call this “interview mode” and it is what happens when a chatter doesn’t qualify properly.

Imagine we met at a party and had the following conversation:

So, where are you from?

The Phillippines

Ok cool. How old are you?

25.

Nice. What do you do for work?

I’m an OnlyFans chatter.

Great. What are your hobbies?

Would you think I am a great conversationalist? 

No, probably not. You’d probably pretend to take a fake phone call and run as far away from me as you could.

Subs will do the virtual equivalent of this, which is to ignore your messages forever.

The way to avoid this is to build a commonality, add some fluff, and then qualify again either deeper or wider.
source_file: Chatter Marines Field Handbook\Qualifying, Commonalities, and Fluff\Avoiding “interview mode” 10b764e8a66e80b2a13ae3115dd25a46.md
key_points: Nice. What do you do for work?

title: Commonalities and why we need to build them
content:
# Commonalities and why we need to build them

A commonality - as we define it - is when you connect some information you got during the qualifying phase to yourself in some way.

When two people meet, there is an early phase in the relationship where they are silently measuring how much they have in common.

The more they believe they have in common, the stronger connection they will feel to the other person.

For example, if you met someone who was from a different country than you, had a different skin color than you, had different political beliefs than you, and was 40 years older than you, you probably wouldn’t feel very connected to them at first.

Sure, you could get to know them and realize that at the end of the day, people are people. But that would take time.

If, on the other hand, you met someone who went to your high school, played the same sport as you, likes the same video games you like, and has the same favorite movie as you, how would you feel about that person?

You’d probably feel VERY close to them.

Building commonalities is just our way of fast-tracking that early phase in a relationship betwen when two people meet and when they feel a strong emotional connection BECAUSE OF THINGS THEY HAVE IN COMMON.
source_file: Chatter Marines Field Handbook\Qualifying, Commonalities, and Fluff\Commonalities and why we need to build them 10b764e8a66e807bad73f894bd2bbc0c.md

title: The juicy info we need
content:
# The juicy info we need

So if qualifying subs is getting information from them, how do we do it elegantly?

The answer is exactly what you think: by asking questions.

However, you don’t want to send him a survey or make him feel like you’re interviewing him on a podcast.

The conversation needs to feel natural. Just two people talking about stuff, like you would in real life.

The difference here is that we are going to make a conscious effort to ask the sub for specific information.

**What we’re looking for is: age, location, profession, and hobbies.**

Ideally, these things would come up in normal conversation. But if they don’t, we need to ask questions.

In my experience, the best thing to start talking about first is what the sub does for work.

Most men spend most of their day working and they will have lots to say about it. 

So a simple, “what do you do for work?” will do wonders to open up the conversation.
source_file: Chatter Marines Field Handbook\Qualifying, Commonalities, and Fluff\The juicy info we need 10b764e8a66e80b088f9ece48f1a418a.md

title: The RIGHT way to build a commonality
content:
# The RIGHT way to build a commonality

Successfully going through the qualification/commonality cycle is somewhat of an art form, but something we can easily break down in linguistic structure.

It looks like this:

1. Qualifying question
2. Qualification
3. Fluff
4. Commonality

Let’s look at an example:

So what do you do for work (qualifying question)

I’m a computer programmer (qualification)

Oh wow, that stuff is super hard (fluff). I tried to learn that once and got so frustrated after 30 minutes that I almost threw my laptop out the window! (commonality)

Every time you go through the cycle, it should be done more or less in this structure.

It doesn’t have to be as short as this, with only one phrase or sentence per section, but it should follow this process.
source_file: Chatter Marines Field Handbook\Qualifying, Commonalities, and Fluff\The RIGHT way to build a commonality 10b764e8a66e80668f75cf70a4cfad0c.md

title: What a good cycle looks like
content:
# What a good cycle looks like

So now that your brain is overloaded with all this stuff about commonalities, qualification, fluff, and god knows what else, how will you know if you’re even doing a good job?

The simple answer is this: when a sub is doing most of the talking, you’re doing a good job.

Of course, not all subs will be talkative and carry the conversation.

But subs who really like the girl, who are in the mood to chat, who are interested in building an emotional connection, and who really like talking about whatever you’ve qualified them on, will send massive paragraphs of text. 

Put even more simply: any time a sub sends you a wall of text, the conversation is going well.

That doesn’t mean that if they DON’T sent that, you’re not doing well. 

What we’re really looking for is some form of investment. Can be an investment of time, effort, or money. Ideally all 3. 

Once we have a decent amount of information on the sub, have built some commonalities, and have gotten them engaged in the conversation, it’s time to move into the next phase: transitioning.
source_file: Chatter Marines Field Handbook\Qualifying, Commonalities, and Fluff\What a good cycle looks like 10c764e8a66e8088a6eecb355a4e00e3.md

title: Why we qualify

The answer: you qualify.

Qualifying a sub is really just a fancy way of saying that we want to get specific infomation from them so we can give them a better experience so they’ll give us more money.

We’lll talk about commonalities later, but without qualifying, you won’t be able to build commonalities with subs.

title: “Me too-ing,” “dicksucking,” and pointless observations (bad things)
content:
# “Me too-ing,” “dicksucking,” and pointless observations (bad things)

Let’s talk about 3 major mistakes chatters make when building commonalities.

Because it’s statistically improbably that the girls we are marketing will have any actual details in common with these subs, we need to get creative.

### Me too-ing

If a sub says he’s a computer programmer, lives in Nebraska, and played football in high school, you can’t *“me too”* your way into a connection.

It’s just not practical. 

However, when the sub says he’s a programmer, you can tell him that you tried to learn programming once but it was so hard that you almost threw your laptop out the window.

Remember: a commonality as we define it is just the act of connecting the information the sub has given you to yourself in some way.

It doesn’t have to be a super strong connection.

It can be a very loose connection.

### Dicksucking

“*Dicksucking*” is when a chatter blows his load over every little detail that a sub gives him about his life.

You’re a computer programmer?! No way! That’s so amazing! OMFG!!!!!!!!!!!

Literally who the fuck cares?

If he says he invented electricty or cured cancer, sure you can react like that.

But chatters mistakenly think that if they are extra nice to subs, that they will like them.

This is not true and it’s a major mistake. You should never do it.

Instead, build a loose commonality. Just be cool baby. Like ice.

### Pointless observations

Pointless observations are when a chatter comments on the information the sub has given him, but fails to connect it to themselves in some way. 

Oh you’re a computer programmer? That must be hard.

Ok… and?

There’s nothing wrong with making these observations. In fact you SHOULD add them in. But that doesn’t mean you skip the commonality part.

Oh you’re a computer programmer? That must be hard. I tried to learn it once and got so frustrated after 30 minutes that I almost threw my laptop out the window.

See the difference?
source_file: Chatter Marines Field Handbook\Qualifying, Commonalities, and Fluff\“Me too-ing,” “dicksucking,” and pointless observa 10b764e8a66e80ff9321ec46b25cb5ae.md

title: 5 reasons subs buy
content:
# 5 reasons subs buy

Before we talk about how to sell, let’s talk about the reasons subs will buy:

1. Buying content during a sexting session
2. Buying one-off content (a specific video)
3. Buying custom content
4. Tipping for a specific purchase (lingerie, etc)
5. Solving a crisis in the model’s life

None of these are “better” than the other, but the more reasons we can stack, the easier it will be for the sub to purchase.

For example, if you just send a PPV to a sub and say, “here baby, watch me fuck myself with this dildo. You’re gonna love it. - $20” then the only reason a sub would buy that is if he’s horny or curious.

But if you’ve done your work properly and built a connection with the sub and provided reasons for why you need the money, then they are more likely to purchase.

In other words, if the sub knows that you are paying for college, short on your rent payment, or have an emergency expense, then they are much more likely to give you money for whatever reason.

Many men like the idea of being to help a woman in her life. 

Whether it’s teaching her something, giving her new experiences, or helping solve a problem for her, this is something that has appealed to men since the beginning of time.

There’s a reason why so many stories feature a hero saving a princess from a terrible evil.

In our story, the hero is the sub, the princess is you, and the terrible evil is financial in nature.

The way that we capitalize on this is by casually mentioning a difficult situation our model is going through and allow the sub to step in and take care of it. 

Here are some potential problems the sub can solve:

3. Helping a pet
4. Paying rent
5. Paying phone bill
6. Paying to fix phone screen
7. Getting hacked
8. No money for food
9. Living in her car

Remember that relative who always hits you up because they need money for something?

Imagine that you are them and you are going to be asking the sub for what you need.

This is an especially powerful tool to use with subs because it allows you to capitalize on the relationship that you’ve built with them over time.

title: Increase the price SLOWLY
content:
# Increase the price SLOWLY

Let me make this very clear to you:

DO NOT JUMP IN PRICE TOO SOON.

Start with a low price, then increase it slowly over the course of the session. 

If you increase in price too quickly, then the sub will get cold feet, back off, and you will alienate them.

Many chatters are too greedy and will jump in price too soon. 

Remember this: less money is better than no money, and it will be better for you to make many small sales than a few large ones.

I’ve seen many subs get burned because the chatter was too greedy and desperate for a sale, asking for $300 in tips.

Make sure you increase the price slowly. This will also allow you to collect more money in a single session.

I saw an example today of a chatter who was running a 5 piece script for $6, $7, $27, $40, and $80.

The sub purchased everything except the final one.

If he had evened out the increases a little bit and added a few more tiers in there, he could have had earned another $150-$200 on top of the $80 that he made from the sale. 

But because he was greedy and went for the kill with the $80 sale, he ended up losing it and getting nothing.

title: Bridging the gap between emotional connection and spending money
content:
# Bridging the gap between emotional connection and spending money

It’s one thing to make them our love slave, but what we also need to do is make the connection for them that people who love each other will spend money on each other. 

So what we want to do is use the same Milton Model linguistic phrasing to insert these ideas into their brain.

Use these sparingly, one or two here and there. I am giving you a bunch of examples for you to play around with, not so that you paste all of them one after another in a conversation.

### **1. Vague and Ambiguous Language**

Use vague language that allows the listener to project their own emotions and reasoning into the situation, while subtly guiding them toward the idea of giving or purchasing as a way to enhance their own happiness or connection with you.

**Example:**

*"sometimes u just get that feeling where u want to do something for someone that makes them happy, right? like u don’t even have to think about it, it’s like u just know that seeing them smile will make u feel good too. it’s wild how the smallest gesture can make everything feel... right."*

This statement uses vague language to suggest that giving or doing something for the other person will lead to mutual happiness. It plants the idea that making a purchase or giving money could be that "small gesture" without saying it outright.

---

### **2. Embedded Suggestions**

Embed the suggestion of making a purchase or giving money within a broader conversation, so the idea feels like a natural, subconscious thought that aligns with their desire to make you happy.

**Example:**

*"it’s funny how when u care about someone, u just want to make them happy... like, without even realizing it, u start thinking of ways to do something special for them, like getting them something u know they’ll love. it feels good, doesn’t it, knowing u’re the one who can make them smile?"*

Here, the embedded suggestion "want to make them happy" and "do something special" subtly encourage them to think about giving or buying something as a way to fulfill that desire.

---

### **3. Pacing and Leading**

Start by pacing the listener’s current feelings or desires, then gradually lead them toward the idea that spending money or making a purchase will deepen their connection with you and make them feel good about themselves.

**Example:**

*"right now, we’re just talking, but u ever notice how the more u connect with someone, the more u wanna do things that make them happy? like, the more u get to know them, the more u want to show them how much u care, and sometimes that means doing something a little extra... it’s like, every time u do, it makes u feel even closer to them."*

In this example, you pace the current conversation and feelings, then lead them toward the idea that doing "something a little extra" (like making a purchase) will enhance the connection.

---

### **4. Cause and Effect**

Link their feelings of wanting to make you happy with the action of giving money or making a purchase, suggesting that this action will naturally lead to more happiness for both of you.

**Example:**

*"the more u care about someone, the more u start to want to do things that show it, right? and it’s funny how when u do something special, like giving them something u know they’ll love, it just makes everything feel... better. like, it makes the connection stronger, and u feel even happier knowing u did that for them."*

This example uses cause and effect to link giving (through money or purchases) with feeling happier and deepening the connection. You’re subtly suggesting that the act of giving will make them feel good.

---

### **5. Presuppositions**

Frame your statements in a way that presupposes the listener is already thinking about making you happy through a purchase or gift. This way, they’re less likely to question the idea and more likely to align with it.

**Example:**

*"when u find someone u care about, it’s only natural to want to give them things that make them happy, right? like, when u know what will bring a smile to their face, it’s just something u do without even thinking twice about it. because u know that every time u give, u’re making them feel special."*

Here, you’re presupposing that they already want to give something (like money or a gift) and that doing so is a natural, automatic response. It bypasses their conscious resistance and makes giving feel inevitable.

---

### **6. Open-Ended Questions**

Ask open-ended questions that invite the listener to imagine how good it would feel to give you something or make a purchase that would make you happy. This helps them reflect on the positive emotions associated with giving.

**Example:**

*"u ever feel like doing something extra for someone just because it’ll make them happy? like, u just know it’ll bring a smile to their face, and that makes u feel even better? what do u think would be the best way to do that?"*

This question invites the listener to think about the best way to make you happy, subtly steering them toward the idea of making a purchase or giving money as a way to achieve that feeling.

---

### **7. Anchoring**

Anchor the idea of giving or making a purchase to positive emotions, such as pleasure, satisfaction, or fulfillment. When they think about giving, they should associate it with feeling good.

**Example:**

*"isn’t it amazing how when u do something for someone u care about, it feels so rewarding? like, every time u give, it’s not just about the thing u’re giving, but the way it makes u feel inside... it’s like, knowing u’re making someone happy makes u feel even more connected and fulfilled."*

Here, you’re anchoring the act of giving to feelings of reward and fulfillment, making the listener associate generosity with positive emotional experiences.

---

### **8. Embedded Commands for Taking Action**

Use embedded commands within the conversation to subtly suggest that they should take action, such as making a purchase or giving money. These commands can be hidden within broader statements so that they don’t feel forced or obvious.

**Example:**

*"sometimes u don’t even realize it, but u just know what someone wants, and before u even think about it, u start to do it... like, u just feel this urge to make them happy, and it all happens so naturally. it’s almost like u just want to make that move and surprise them with something special."*

Here, the embedded commands "do it" and "want to make that move" subtly encourage the listener to take action in a way that feels natural and self-motivated.

---

### **9. Make It Seem Inevitable**

Frame the act of giving or purchasing as something that’s inevitable and will naturally happen because of how much they care about you. This lowers resistance and makes the decision feel like the logical next step.

**Example:**

*"when u care about someone, it’s only a matter of time before u find urself wanting to give them something special, right? like, it’s not even a question, u just know that doing something nice for them will make u both feel good. it’s like u can’t help but want to give more because of how good it feels."*

By framing it as inevitable ("it’s only a matter of time"), you reduce resistance and make it feel like giving or making a purchase is something they’ll naturally want to do.

---

### **10. Storytelling or Metaphors**

Use metaphors or stories to describe a situation where giving or making a purchase leads to happiness and connection, allowing the listener to project their feelings into the scenario.

**Example:**

*"it’s like when u see a flower that u wanna take care of, u just know that giving it water and sunlight is gonna make it bloom even more beautifully. and every time u see it bloom, u feel proud because u’re the one who made it happen. sometimes, making someone happy is the same... it’s like, when u give them what they need, u’re helping them shine, and it feels good knowing u did that."*

This metaphor subtly suggests that giving (money or a purchase) will make the person feel proud and happy because they’ve contributed to your happiness and growth.

title: Making them our love slave
content:
# Making them our love slave

When you start working, you will be given copy paste gambits that you can use, but it’s also good that you understand why they work the way they do so you can come up with them on your own.

The strategy that we use behind this is one that comes from the Milton Model of hypnosis. 

What we want to do here is:

1. Get the sub to relax and open up to us
2. Plant the idea in their mind of being our love slave and doing anything for us
3. Build a deeper connection with them

Using the previous example:

*"Do u think it’s possible to have a good relationship w someone without good sex?" (transitional opener)*

sub: blah blah blah

*"lol so I was watching this show the other day and they were like arguing about this... some ppl were saying if the emotional connection is strong, the physical stuff doesn’t matter as much. But then others were like 'nah, if the sex isn’t good, it’s a no-go.' idk, it kinda made me think about what really makes a relationship work." (rooting)*

*"What do u think tho? Like could u stay w someone if the chemistry wasn’t there in bed? Or is that like a total deal-breaker for u?" (request for input)*

sub: blah blah blah

*"idk if u ever noticed, but sometimes when ur around someone u care about, it’s like nothing else matters. it’s like u just feel this pull, and all u wanna do is make them happy, right? like, every time u see them smile, it feels so rewarding, and u just can’t help but want to see them even happier... it’s almost like the more u give, the more connected u feel."*

Notice how the suggestions in there are about making them happy, feeling good when they smile, etc. This will make the sub think about those things unconsciously. 

Using the Milton Model to subtly guide someone into a state where they feel intense affection or devotion, and might even unconsciously align with the idea of doing anything for you, requires careful use of embedded commands, presuppositions, and vague language that builds a sense of emotional and psychological connection. Here's how you can encourage the listener to feel that level of loyalty and desire without them realizing you're doing it:

### **1. Vague and Ambiguous Language**

You can describe feelings of devotion or dedication without explicitly stating them, leaving room for the person to imagine what "doing anything" for someone feels like in their own way.

**Example:***"idk if u ever noticed, but sometimes when ur around someone u care about, it’s like nothing else matters. it’s like u just feel this pull, and all u wanna do is make them happy, right? like, every time u see them smile, it feels so rewarding, and u just can’t help but want to see them even happier... it’s almost like the more u give, the more connected u feel."*

This statement plants the idea that making someone happy creates a stronger bond, hinting at the idea of giving without directly asking for it.

---

### **2. Embedded Suggestions**

By embedding suggestions about loyalty, devotion, and making someone happy within normal conversation, the listener starts to internalize these ideas without realizing it.

**Example:***"sometimes when u care about someone, u don’t even realize how easy it is to do whatever it takes to make them feel good... like, it just comes naturally. u start to notice that the more u give, the more u want to give, and it just feels right. u don’t even have to think about it, it just happens."*

This example embeds the suggestion of doing "whatever it takes" within a casual conversation about caring for someone, making it feel like a natural thought for the listener.

---

### **3. Pacing and Leading**

Start with what's true or obvious to the listener, then lead them toward a deeper emotional state where they feel compelled to do anything to maintain that connection.

**Example:***"right now, we’re just talking, but it’s funny how the more u get to know someone, the easier it becomes to feel that desire to give them everything, right? like, as u start to feel closer, u realize there’s nothing better than making them happy... and u just know u’d do anything to keep that feeling going."*

Here, you’re pacing by acknowledging the conversation, then leading them to the conclusion that giving everything to someone else is natural and rewarding.

---

### **4. Cause and Effect**

Link their feelings of happiness and satisfaction to the idea of devotion, suggesting that their own joy increases when they give more to you.

**Example:***"the more u focus on making someone happy, the more it seems like ur own happiness grows, right? like, the more u give, the deeper the connection feels, and it’s like u can’t help but feel this urge to do whatever it takes to keep that bond alive... and it feels so good to see how much they appreciate it."*

This structure suggests that their own happiness and fulfillment is directly tied to making the other person happy, reinforcing the desire to give more.

---

### **5. Presuppositions**

Use language that assumes the listener already feels a deep connection and desire to do anything for the other person, bypassing their conscious defenses.

**Example:***"when u find someone who really understands u, it’s only natural to wanna give them everything, right? like, when u feel that close, it’s almost automatic that u’d do anything just to see them smile, to make them feel good... because u know it’s worth it."*

The presupposition here is that they’ve already found someone they feel deeply connected to and that doing anything for them is already something they want to do.

---

### **6. Utilization**

Use whatever the listener shares with you, such as their feelings or experiences, to frame the idea of devotion as something they are naturally inclined to do.

**Example:***"u know how sometimes u get that feeling when ur with someone, and u just know u’d do anything for them, without even thinking about it? like, the more u’re around them, the more u want to see them happy, and it’s not even a question, it’s just what u want to do... it’s almost like u’re driven by that feeling."*

This example utilizes the listener's own potential experiences or feelings of devotion, making them reflect on those sensations in a way that encourages loyalty and dedication.

---

### **7. Mind Reading**

This technique involves making statements that suggest you understand what the listener is feeling, making them feel understood and aligning them with the idea of doing anything for you.

**Example:***"u know, i can tell u’re the kind of person who really cares deeply... like, when u’re with someone who means a lot to u, it’s almost like u can’t help but want to give everything... it’s who u are. and i think that’s such a rare thing, to find someone who’s willing to do whatever it takes to make the person they care about feel special."*

By suggesting that you "know" they’re the type to be devoted, they are more likely to accept that as part of their identity and act in accordance with it.

---

### **8. Open-Ended Questions**

Ask open-ended questions that invite the listener to think about the lengths they would go to for someone they care about, subtly encouraging them to align with the idea of devotion.

**Example:***"have u ever felt so connected to someone that u’d do anything just to make them smile? like, no matter what it took, u knew it would be worth it just to see them happy?"*

This question invites the listener to reflect on a time they felt such devotion, priming them to consider that feeling again in the present moment.

---

### **9. Metaphor and Storytelling**

Use stories or metaphors to describe loyalty and devotion in a way that allows the listener to relate it to their own experiences, further embedding the idea of dedication without being overt.

**Example:***"it’s like when u find a rare flower, and u just wanna take care of it, nurture it, do whatever u can to make sure it grows... and u don’t even realize how much u’re willing to give until u’re already doing it. sometimes, that’s how it is with someone u care about... u don’t even have to think, u just know u’d do whatever it takes to make them feel cherished."*

This metaphor subtly suggests that devotion is a natural, almost automatic response to caring deeply for someone.

---

By using these Milton Model techniques covertly, you can guide someone into feeling intense affection and devotion without them realizing you’re leading the conversation that way. The key is to be subtle, letting them come to their own conclusions and feelings, while you gently nudge their thoughts in the direction of loyalty and a desire to please.

title: Rinsing sugar daddies (prep)
content:
# Rinsing sugar daddies (prep)

**Guide to rinsing sugar daddies**

[](https://lh7-rt.googleusercontent.com/docsz/AD_4nXc_LwQxSO8x6E2TfIB5YH-KY0te49ShNfld39D8lKCXZxia78BGoLy3MuL2KEF3V7NSnNT522NvIpLR69Tn-gEEyjwYLNd7b4NxWiPKoYzUzGYx-YCGDasQtEjX9TXEYEXESwPGu6YmcKQr6gmM2ES8_bVa?key=vHnL65GptFrCno5B2V7V-g)

**Original video: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=67Ehonw_VYk**

The guide provides tips on how to successfully get money from a sugar daddy by focusing on creating a pleasant, feminine, and dependent persona.

The speaker emphasizes the importance of acting happy, playful, and slightly naive, to make the man feel needed and important. She advises against directly asking for money and instead suggests creating a dynamic where the sugar daddy becomes accustomed to helping and providing.

The strategy is built around boosting the man’s confidence and making him feel like a gentleman who enjoys taking care of the woman.

**Key Action Points:**

1. **Play the Role**: When meeting a sugar daddy, be overly happy, smile a lot, and act slightly naive or dependent, as this makes the man feel responsible and invested.
    - *“Happy people spend money... Happy people want to make you happy.”*
2. **Create Dependency**: Continuously ask for small favors, such as help with ordering food or choosing wine, to subtly establish a dynamic where he becomes accustomed to helping you.
    - *“Everything you need, ask him to help. Get him in the habit of helping from day one.”*
3. **Compliment and Flirt**: Compliment his appearance, physique, or choices to boost his ego and create a bond.
    - *“Compliment his physique, even if he doesn’t have one... You felt his muscles!”*
4. **Make Him Feel Like a Gentleman**: Praise his actions throughout the date, such as when he pays the bill or helps with small things, to reinforce his role as a provider.
    - *“You’re such a gentleman... He now has to live up to that title.”*
5. **Delay Financial Discussions**: Avoid bringing up money until after the date or in subsequent meetings when the man is more invested in you.
    - *“Don’t ask for money right away. Wait until after you’ve built a connection.”*
6. **Use Subtle Financial Hints**: After the initial connection, gradually introduce financial needs by asking for help with things like a parking fee or small bills, which eventually lead to bigger requests.
    - *“You start small, and then you ask for more over time as they become more invested.”*
7. **Keep the Relationship Fun and Light**: Avoid making the man feel pressured or that the relationship is purely transactional. Create enjoyable, memorable experiences.
    - *“Make it fun and adventurous. That way, he associates you with positive emotions and memories.”*
8. **Be Careful With Direct Requests**: When asking for bigger financial contributions, tie the request to something that makes him feel good, like you needing money for a job loss or family emergency.
    - *“Play the victim... You lost your job, you helped your sick mom... He’ll feel sorry and offer help.”*
9. **Look Your Best**: Always look better than your online profile or past meetings to impress him in person.
    - *“You need to outshine your profile picture when you meet in person.”*
10. **Customize Based on the Sugar Daddy**: Adjust your strategy depending on the man’s wealth, attractiveness, and expectations. Some will offer money easily, while others need more persuasion.
- *“You might get the money upfront or have to work for it, depending on the guy.”*

**Quotes:**

- *“Happy people spend money. If they’re not spending, they’re not happy.”*
- *“He needs to feel responsible for you; once he feels responsible, he’ll give.”*
- *“You don’t ask for money upfront; you make them feel good first.”*
- *“If he feels like a gentleman, he’ll pay without you even asking.”*
- *“Keep asking for small things, and when the big ask comes, he’ll be used to helping you.”*

Here are some specific things the speaker advises the viewer to say to the sugar daddy during different phases of the interaction:

### **During the Initial Conversation:**

1. **Compliment and Flirt:**
    - *"Do you remember my name? I was hoping you would."* (Playfully flirtatious.)
    - *"I felt a little muscle when I hugged you. Do you work out? You must play sports."*
2. **Be Excited and Dependent:**
    - *"Oh my God, this is such a nice place. I don’t know what to order. Can you help me decide?"*
    - *"Would you suggest a wine to go with this? I heard pairing wine with dinner makes it taste better."* (Establishes a sense of needing help.)
    - *"What would you recommend I try here? You have good taste."*
3. **Play the Damsel in Distress:**
    - *"Oh, I don’t have any cash for valet. I’ll need to go to the ATM."* (This encourages him to step in and pay for things without asking directly.)

### **After the first conversation:**

1. **Initiating Financial Conversations:**
    - *"Did you have a good time? I sure did. I think we’ll have a lot of fun together, and I feel like we’re a good match."* (Building chemistry before mentioning money.)
    - *"I really feel like there’s a lot more to discover between us. Maybe we can talk about what you want from this relationship?"* (Opening the door for a financial arrangement.)
2. **Hinting at Financial Help:**
    - *"I got a ticket and I don’t know if I should go to court or just pay it. What do you think I should do?"* (This is followed by mentioning that you can’t afford it, prompting him to offer help.)
    - *"I just lost my job, and I’m so stressed about having to look for another one. I don’t know what to do."* (Leads him to offer financial support.)

### **Establishing a Financial Arrangement:**

1. **Casual Request for a Monthly Allowance:**
    - *"My bills are only around $1,000 a month, but I can cut back if I need to. What do you think?"* (Suggests a manageable amount, while making it seem like you’re willing to sacrifice.)
2. **Playfully Discussing Large Expenses:**
    - *"I wish I could get new shoes or lingerie. What do you think would look good on me?"* (This subtly ties in something that benefits him, making him more likely to pay for it.)
3. **Asking for Support Without Directly Asking:**
    - *"If I didn’t have to work, I could spend more time with you. I could be waiting for you when you get home, in lingerie."*

By using these kinds of phrases, the speaker advises creating a dynamic where the sugar daddy naturally wants to help and provide financially, without the woman explicitly asking for money right away.

**Additional phrases to use:**

Certainly! Here are more specific things the speaker advises the viewer to say, categorized by context, to encourage financial support without being too direct:

### **During the First Conversation**

1. **Flirt and Make Him Feel Important:**
    - *"You have great taste; maybe you could help me pick out something nice sometime."*
    - *"I love how you took charge with the waiter earlier; it’s so attractive when a man knows how to lead."*
    - *"Wow, this restaurant is so nice. You really know how to pick the best places."* (Showing admiration.)
2. **Play the Helpless Role:**
    - *"I’ve never been to a place like this before. What do you recommend I try?"* (Appealing to his expertise.)
    - *"I’m not sure how to choose... Do you think you could help me decide what’s best?"*
    - *"What kind of wine pairs well with this? I’ve never had someone help me with that before."*
3. **Encourage Him to Take Charge:**
    - *"I feel like I could just trust you to make all the decisions tonight."* (Building his confidence.)
    - *"You seem so knowledgeable; can you help me with...?"*

### **After the Date/Starting Financial Discussions:**

1. **Open the Door for Financial Support:**
    - *"I had such a great time with you tonight. I feel like we have really good chemistry."*
    - *"I think we could have a lot of fun together. How do you feel about seeing me more often?"* (Implying the need for support to continue seeing him.)
2. **Subtle Financial Hints:**
    - *"I had such a great time, but I’m so stressed about this unexpected expense that came up. It’s really weighing on me."* (Letting him offer help.)
    - *"I just feel overwhelmed sometimes with everything I have to take care of. I wish I could just focus on being happy."*
3. **Transition to Financial Conversations:**
    - *"I think we have a really good connection, and I want to spend more time with you. Maybe we could talk about what kind of arrangement we could have?"*
    - *"I really enjoy your company, and I think we could be a great match. Let’s discuss how we can make this work."* (Suggesting a financial arrangement without being too direct.)

### **Building the Financial Dynamic:**

1. **Casually Asking for Financial Help:**
    - *"Oh no, I forgot to bring cash for the valet. I’ll have to find an ATM."* (Encouraging him to cover small expenses.)
    - *"I don’t want to trouble you, but I had this unexpected bill come up... I just don’t know how I’m going to manage it."*
2. **Hinting at Bigger Expenses:**
    - *"You know, my rent is due soon, and I’m feeling a little stressed. Do you think you could help me figure out a solution?"*
    - *"I’ve been thinking about getting a new dress or shoes for our next date. What do you think would look best on me?"* (Tying the expense to something that benefits him.)
3. **Establishing a Monthly Arrangement:**
    - *"I’m really enjoying our time together. I think we could spend a lot more time together if I wasn’t so worried about money."* (Gently leading into an allowance conversation.)
    - *"I would love to spend more time with you, but it’s hard when I have to juggle work and bills. Maybe we could work something out so I can focus more on you?"*

### **Follow-Up Conversations and Escalating Support:**

1. **Continue the Dependency:**
    - *"I had such a great time with you, but I’m feeling a bit overwhelmed. I’ve got this unexpected expense, and I don’t know what to do."* (Making him feel like the hero by offering help.)
    - *"I wish I didn’t have to worry about bills so I could just relax and enjoy life with you."*
2. **Discussing Financial Needs Directly:**
    - *"I really think we have a good thing going. If you want to keep seeing me, maybe we could discuss something regular, like helping me with my bills."* (Suggesting a regular allowance.)
    - *"I’m so stressed about money right now. I wish I had someone who could help take care of me."*
3. **Finalizing the Financial Arrangement:**
    - *"I’ve really enjoyed our time together. What do you think about helping me with a monthly allowance? That way, I can be stress-free when I’m with you."*
    - *"It would make things so much easier if we had an arrangement. I think it would allow us to focus on enjoying our time together more."* (Sealing the deal for financial support.)

### **Fun, Playful Suggestions for Bigger Requests:**

1. **Making Financial Requests Fun:**
    - *"I love those shoes. Do you think I’d look good in them? Maybe you could help me get a pair."* (Tying shopping to him.)
    - *"Oh, I love that perfume. You have such good taste! Maybe you can take me shopping for some."*
2. **Sparking His Imagination for Future Support:**
    - *"I’ve always wanted to go to that spa. I bet I’d look amazing after a full day of pampering."* (Encouraging him to pay for a luxury experience.)
    - *"I’ve been wanting to get some new lingerie for our next date. Do you think you could help me pick something sexy?"*

By subtly working these lines into conversations and letting him feel like the provider and protector, the speaker encourages building a dynamic where the sugar daddy naturally wants to give and support financially.

title: Step 1: Transitional opener
content:
# Step 1: Transitional opener

Once you’ve gone through the qual/comm cycle several times and are ready to transition, the first thing you want to do is drop in a transitional opener.

This can be a statement or a question that subtly shifts the topic of conversation away from the information-gathering phase and into the selling phase.

For example:

*"Do u think it’s possible to have a good relationship w someone without good sex?" (transitional opener)*

The goal of the transitional opener is 3 fold:

Move the conversation away from information-gathering into the beginning of the selling phase

Move the conversation into more sexual topics

Create a more intimate relationship with the sub

Once you go through the entire cycle, you’ll be able to build additional commonalities with them. Except now instead of building them on superficial topics like work or location, you’ll be able to build them on more intimate topics like sexual or relationship desires.

### 

###
source_file: Chatter Marines Field Handbook\Transitioning to selling\Step 1 Transitional opener 10c764e8a66e8085b2e4e2a90d7a5722.md

title: Step 2: Rooting
content:
# Step 2: Rooting

When you change the subject during a conversation, people will naturally be a little confused.

One minute you’re talking about boring stuff, and then all of a sudden you segway into something sexual.

Even though in the back of their mind these guys probably know what you’re doing, you want to do them the courtesy of coming up with a logical reason why you are talking about it anyway.

It’s all part of giving the sub a good experience. 

The rooting phase is all about giving a plausible reason why you are bringing up this topic.

Using the previous example:

*"Do u think it’s possible to have a good relationship w someone without good sex?" (transitional opener)*

sub: blah blah blah

*"lol so I was watching this show the other day and they were like arguing about this... some ppl were saying if the emotional connection is strong, the physical stuff doesn’t matter as much. But then others were like 'nah, if the sex isn’t good, it’s a no-go.' idk, it kinda made me think about what really makes a relationship work." (rooting)*

Framed this way, it makes it clear to the sub that you are not bringing up this sexual topic as a way to trick him into touching his dick and spending money with you.

You are genuinely curious because of the conversation you overheard.

You can come up with whatever reason you want. It can be a dream you had, a personal experience, a documentary you watched, a conversation with a friend - whatever.

But the point is that you frame it in a way that makes it clear that there is a REASON WHY YOU ARE ASKING so it doesn’t seem weird. 

### 

###
source_file: Chatter Marines Field Handbook\Transitioning to selling\Step 2 Rooting 10c764e8a66e808ba541fa3e1a1afa1f.md

title: Step 3: Request for input
content:
# Step 3: Request for input

If all we do is the transitional opener and the rooting, then we run the risk of the sub not interacting at all.

And if you remember, one of the main goals of chatting is to get the sub to invest.

Not necessarily with money, but with time and effort as well.

By requesting input from the sub, we are kind of strongarming them into participating in the conversation.

Note that we may not ALWAYS need to do this. I would say that at least 50% of the time the sub will naturally give their opinion anyway. But in case they don’t, we need to be proactive and ask for it.

Using the previous example:

*"Do u think it’s possible to have a good relationship w someone without good sex?" (transitional opener)*

sub: blah blah blah

*"lol so I was watching this show the other day and they were like arguing about this... some ppl were saying if the emotional connection is strong, the physical stuff doesn’t matter as much. But then others were like 'nah, if the sex isn’t good, it’s a no-go.' idk, it kinda made me think about what really makes a relationship work." (rooting)*

*"What do u think tho? Like could u stay w someone if the chemistry wasn’t there in bed? Or is that like a total deal-breaker for u?" (request for input)*

It’s very likely here that the sub will give their opinion, hopefully giving some justification for why they did so.
source_file: Chatter Marines Field Handbook\Transitioning to selling\Step 3 Request for input 10c764e8a66e80778ae8c80a1ab94455.md

title: Step 4: Hypnosis
content:
# Step 4: Hypnosis

The 4th and final phase is designed to pull the sub into your reality. 

This is where we get them really in the moment, really feeling themselves, and trying to push them into a strong connection with you.

We want the sub to feel like you are the only person in his universe, that you are the only one there, so that he is fully in the moment and much more open to suggestions from you.

Using the previous example:

*"Do u think it’s possible to have a good relationship w someone without good sex?" (transitional opener)*

sub: blah blah blah

*"lol so I was watching this show the other day and they were like arguing about this... some ppl were saying if the emotional connection is strong, the physical stuff doesn’t matter as much. But then others were like 'nah, if the sex isn’t good, it’s a no-go.' idk, it kinda made me think about what really makes a relationship work." (rooting)*

*"What do u think tho? Like could u stay w someone if the chemistry wasn’t there in bed? Or is that like a total deal-breaker for u?" (request for input)*

sub: blah blah blah

*“idk if u ever noticed this but sometimes when ur with someone, u can feel everything shift... like, without even thinking about it, everything else just kinda fades away, right? it’s like... time slows down, and ur just totally in the moment, like nothing else matters except the way u connect... u know that feeling when their touch sends little tingles through u, or when they look at u, it feels like the whole world gets quieter... and u just start sinking deeper into that feeling, like u could stay there forever?*

*i think it's wild how u can just let go and get so lost in that space, where it’s just u two...*
source_file: Chatter Marines Field Handbook\Transitioning to selling\Step 4 Hypnosis 10c764e8a66e804ab538c68dd1d627ab.md

title: Step 5: Seductive tease
content:
# Step 5: Seductive tease

Now that we’ve broached the subject, it’s time to inject some more sexuality into the conversation.

We don’t want to be too overt with it because then it would be obvious.

But by teasing, we create some space for the sub to chase.

This is extremely powerful because by the sub feeling like he is doing the chasing, it reverses the buyer seller dynamic.

Instead of YOU trying to sell the sub, now he is the one who is engaged and trying to take things sexual.

Let’s assume the gambit you are running is talking about what turns men on.

You could say:

*not saying i’d figure out what ur thing is but... i might already have an idea ;)*
source_file: Chatter Marines Field Handbook\Transitioning to selling\Step 5 Seductive tease 10d764e8a66e8018a0d7f66085f60712.md

title: The importance of transitioning
content:
# The importance of transitioning

Transitioning to selling is arguably one of the most important phases of the chatting process.

We have done all this work, sent all these messages, qualified, built commonalities, and thrown in a hefty amount of fluff all for the purpose of getting the sub engaged in the conversation.

Now that we’ve done that, we want to move the topic of conversation towards a more flirtatious or sexual tone.

But what we DON’T want to do is just send a PPV out of the blue or have it be too jarring.

This is where transitioning comes on.

Done properly, transitioning brings up a seemingly innocent topic and gets the sub thinking about sex.

Once their imagination is stimulated, it’s just a matter of time before the conversation becomes sexual.

And once the convo becomes sexual, then we can start to get some money from them by selling content.

Transitioning is done in 3 phases:

1. Transitional opener
2. Rooting
3. Request for input
4. Hypnosis

Whereas with the qual/comm cycle we try to get the sub talking, the transition phase is where the chatter will do most of the talking.
source_file: Chatter Marines Field Handbook\Transitioning to selling\The importance of transitioning c6d9bf8aa3e94914be796ee52623d44b.md

title: Broken phone screen
content:
# Broken phone screen

### **1. Opening: Emotional Distress/General Question**

*hey... do you ever have those days where everything just goes wrong? i’ve been dealing with something that’s been driving me crazy lately, and i don’t know how to fix it.*

---

### **2. Rooting (Reason for Asking)**

title: Different religion
content:
# Different religion

### **0. Opening Remark**

*i overheard the weirdest conversation at work today! like, it wasn’t a big deal or anything, but it really made me stop and think. just one of those random moments where you can’t help but wonder what you’d do.*

---

### **1. Relating an Experience**

*so, these two people were talking about dating someone from a different religion. one girl was saying how her boyfriend is Jewish, but she’s Catholic, and it’s been creating some tension between them because they’re not sure if they see the future the same way. she really likes him, but they’ve been arguing about little things, like how they’d raise kids or how to celebrate holidays. i guess it's starting to bother both of them.*

---

### **2. Opinion/Take on the Situation**

*i feel like it would depend on the couple, you know? like, religion can be a big deal for some people, but for others, it’s not that serious. i think as long as they respect each other’s beliefs, it could work. but at the same time, i could see how it might be hard if they can’t agree on important stuff like raising kids.*

---

### **3. Asking for Opinion**

*what do you think? would you ever date someone who’s from a different religion? like, say you’re Jewish, would you date someone who’s Christian or Muslim? i wonder if it’s more of a guy thing to be chill about it or if everyone feels like it’s a big deal sometimes.*

---

### **4. Building Commonality**

*it’s funny, because i had a friend who went through the exact same thing with her boyfriend. she’s Muslim, and he was Christian, and it was fine at first, but after a while, they started having issues about their different traditions and beliefs. i guess when it gets serious, stuff like that really starts to come up. it made me think about how tricky it can be to balance love and personal beliefs.*
source_file: Chatter Marines Field Handbook\Gambits\Emotional connection\Different religion 10d764e8a66e806bbd65c581f594a55a.md

# Is good sex important

### **0. Opening Remark**

*i kinda feel like good sex is definitely important, but maybe it’s not everything. i mean, there’s so much more to a relationship than just physical stuff, but at the same time, if there’s no chemistry, that could cause problems too. it’s tricky, i guess. i feel like it’s all about balance—like, it matters, but maybe not as much for some people.*

### **3. Asking for Opinion**

*what about you? do you think good sex is really important in a relationship, or is it more about everything else, like connection and trust? i’m curious if guys think about it the same way or if it’s more of a “girl thing” to worry about.*

---

### **4. Building Commonality**

*oh wow, that’s interesting. honestly, i had a conversation kinda like that with someone i dated before. we were great in every other way, but we couldn’t connect physically, and it ended up being a bigger deal than i expected. i think everyone has different needs in a relationship, but it’s funny how stuff like that can sometimes make or break things, even when everything else is perfect.*
