title: Taste in music
content:
# Taste in music

### **0. Opening Remark**

*i was scrolling through tiktok today, and something kinda funny popped up that got me thinking. it wasn’t anything crazy, but definitely one of those “hmm, i wonder what other people would think” moments.*

---

### **1. Relating an Experience**

*this couple on tiktok was doing one of those “relationship question” challenges, and the question was whether having the same taste in music is important. the girl was saying she thinks it’s a big deal because music is such a huge part of her life, and she wants to share that with someone. but the guy said he didn’t think it mattered as long as they got along in other ways. it was kinda cute but also made me wonder.*

---

### **2. Opinion/Take on the Situation**

*i’m definitely on the side that thinks it’s important. like, if i can’t share my favorite songs with someone, or we’re always arguing about what to listen to in the car, that would kinda suck, you know? music can set a vibe, and i think having that in common brings people closer. but maybe not everyone feels that way.*

---

### **3. Asking for Opinion**

*what about you? do you think having the same taste in music is important in a relationship, or is it just one of those things that doesn’t matter that much? i’m curious if it’s something guys care about as much as girls do.*

---

### **4. Building Commonality**

*haha, that’s interesting. it’s funny because i dated someone who was super into music, and we had completely different tastes. like, he loved rock, and i’m more into pop and r&b. it was actually a bigger deal than i expected, because we couldn’t even agree on what to play when we were together. i think little things like that can either bring people closer or make things awkward.*
source_file: Chatter Marines Field Handbook\Gambits\Emotional connection\Taste in music 10d764e8a66e80b68c11c025af63a7cc.md

title: Who lies more
content:
# Who lies more

### **0. Opening Remark**

*something kinda funny came up today, and i just had to share it with you. i heard the weirdest debate that totally made me stop and think… it was one of those “wait, what do i actually believe about this?” moments.*

---

### **1. Relating an Experience**

*so, i was chatting with a friend, and she was talking about how her boyfriend accused her of lying about something super small, like where she was hanging out. they ended up getting into this whole argument, and then she told him that guys lie way more than girls do. and of course, he disagreed and was like, “no, girls lie way more, especially about feelings and little things.” it got me thinking about who actually lies more in relationships, men or women?*

---

### **2. Opinion/Take on the Situation**

*i kinda think it depends. like, maybe men lie more when it comes to keeping secrets or trying to protect someone’s feelings, but i feel like women might tell those little white lies just to avoid unnecessary drama. but i also feel like everyone’s different, so it’s not that black and white, you know?*

---

### **3. Asking for Opinion**

*what do you think? do you feel like men tend to lie more, or is it something both sides do equally? i’m curious if you’ve ever caught someone lying to you before… and if it felt like something only guys or girls do more often.*

---

### **4. Building Commonality**

*it’s funny, because i remember i had an ex who would lie about the smallest things just to avoid any conflict. it would drive me crazy because half the time it wasn’t even necessary. i guess we all lie sometimes, but it’s interesting how different people have totally different “lie thresholds.” like, have you ever noticed how some people just feel like they have to cover up the tiniest details?*
source_file: Chatter Marines Field Handbook\Gambits\Emotional connection\Who lies more 10d764e8a66e80768321c674ee4aaf9c.md

title: Script sale, 4/5 (greed is bad)
content:
# Script sale, 4/5 (greed is bad)

Chatter did a good job warming up a sub and selling him some PPVs. However, he got greedy at the end and priced the final PPV too high, losing out on the final sale and possibly burning the sub. 

However, I really like the qualifying/commonalities here. Note that it if you are a native English speaker, it may seem clunky and awkward. But that extra bit of dialogue between you and the sub will help you earn more from them over a longer period of time. 

Overall very good, save for the part at the end where he tries to price the finally PPV way too high.

Read through the entire chat and then see my feedback at the bottom.

title: Curving a meetup request
content:
# Curving a meetup request

As you know meetups are strictly forbidden on OF, but many subs believe that the model is local to them or at least willing to meet. In this case, the chatter successfully curved a meetup request from a sub who specifically said: “Prove to me that we’ll meet!” Conversations that head into this territory are very dangerous and can lead to accounts getting locked. But what the chatter did here was good.

title: Mixer Gambit
content:
# Mixer Gambit

This is a clever gambit where the chatter talks about how they have taken up baking as a hobby and want to buy a new mixer. 

They send a picture of the mixer and talk about how they’re saving for it, how they’ve gotten a certain portion saved but are working towards the rest. 

Works well.

Fun fact: you can change the price as well by pressing F12 to inspect element.

Context:

title: Nothing wrong with a 100% buy rate
content:
# Nothing wrong with a 100% buy rate

A major problem chatters have is being greedy and impatient.

This leads to inflated prices, buyer’s remorse, and no repeat buying.

Our goal with subs is to have people we can go to all the time any time for money.

And the way we do this is by starting out with smaller sales and working our way up slowly. 

If a sub buys 100% of the time and spends less money, that’s better than them buying 50% and spending more money. Especially if there is a high risk they will be burned in the process.

Context:
source_file: Chatter Marines Field Handbook\Example conversations\Leonel\Nothing wrong with a 100% buy rate 112764e8a66e804f8f01cb0f6686ccb8.md

title: Referencing past convos to show care
content:
# Referencing past convos to show care

One of the most important things for chatters to do is take a genuine interest in a subscriber. They are not just an ATM machine for you to extract money from, and if you treat them that way they will feel it and avoid you.

One of the main reasons for qualifying them is so that we have information we can reference in future conversations. They will think, “oh wow, they really were paying attention to me.”

And when you reference what they said in previous convos, they will feel that you actually care. AND YOU SHOULD.

Context:
source_file: Chatter Marines Field Handbook\Example conversations\Leonel\Referencing past convos to show care 111764e8a66e8070bc2cdca4505eae6e.md

# Showing the sub a good time

Most of the money you make from chatting will come from a small number of subs. You are not going to sell to everyone.. The chatters who do numbers sell A LOT to a small number of people.

So that means when you come across these people who like your model, are in the mood, and have money, that you want to get as much out of them as possible.

This is a convo of a chatter running a good sequence where he does just that. 

Context:

title: When you get lucky
content:
# When you get lucky

This is a weird one…

The chatter send a $100 PPV to a sub, missed a week of work, and when he came back somehow convinced the sub to buy it (without really trying to convince him) by talking about the PPV.

He managed to do such a good job getting the sub in the mood, that the sub actually went back and bought the PPV.

The chatter made no attempt to close him, no pressure, nothing. Just talked about it.

Let me make it clear that this is not a reliable strategy and it is 100x better to do things the normal way in a sexting session - i.e. small sales that build gradually into larger ones for multiple purchases in a single session.

title: How to break rapport and still sell
content:
# How to break rapport and still sell

This chatter is lucky to have very good English and verbal skills which he uses to his advantage in this conversation.

He does something here that we call “breaking rapport.”

Breaking rapport is where you disrupt the positive connection between you and someone else.

The part where he rips on the sub for not being able to hold a conversation was very good.

Breaking rapport - done properly - will cause the other person to chase you and work for your approval. I’m sure you see how this can be very useful in sales.

What’s interesting is that the chatter didn’t even realize he was doing this, yet it still worked.

If anything, the chatter may have played it a little TOO cool here. The sub was clearly looking for more content and eager to spend more money. 

Context:
source_file: Chatter Marines Field Handbook\Example conversations\Other Chatters\Billy\How to break rapport and still sell 112764e8a66e800c8c39c51dd51f186e.md

title: Ask and ye shall receive
content:
# Ask and ye shall receive

The difference between chatters who make money and chatters who don’t make money is that the ones who make money ask for the money.

If you are too scared to ask for the money and just rely on people to give it to you, then you will not do well.

You have to actually ask for it. 

Here, the chatter got the sub to pay for a flight ticket just by asking for it. Granted, this guy is a whale and spends money on everything. But he wasn’t offering, he had to be asked.

title: Reviving dead VIP
content:
# Reviving dead VIP

This is a convo where the chatter revived a dead VIP who used to spend a lot of money. Most of it is good, except for the opener. “Hi babe” is a shit opener and the chatter straight up got lucky with such a boring opener. Definitely should have been personalized and more compelling. But the sub responded and sales were made.

Also a little weird how part of the sequence talks about “oh I’m in the shower now” - like what is she in the shower, recording a video, uploading it to her computer, writing out a PPV description, and sending it to a sub? According to the sub, I guess so. They’re truly retarded.

title: When the sub is at work.
content:
# When the sub is at work.

Subs won’t always buy the entire sequence, but that doesn’t mean you shouldn’t try. Since the sub was at work, it’s very unlikely he’s going to pop into the bathroom to rub one out to some OF content. A different approach is required. 

When a sub is at work, try a slower burn. You don’t want to just coax them into buying every single little thing, mix in some more casual conversation.

“you’re so naughty, can’t believe you’re doing this while at work.”

“if I was your boss and saw what you’re doing, I’d so fire you haha”

“wow I can’t believe they pay you to sit here and talk to me while I rub my pussy”

You’re going to have to work a little harder
